description:
Dammit Valve, you’re not making this easy for me. Right now the official, first-party Steam store is selling the base model Steam Deck for $80 off, bringing its price down to just $319.20. This is not a used or refurbished unit; this a new, base Steam Deck, no tricks, no punches pulled.

And that’s a great freakin’ price to get in on the portable PC fun, even three years after the device launched. You can’t really find any of the Windows-based alternatives for under $500, and even then you need to hunt for rare sales or refurb hardware. Considering how pricey the Switch 2 is looking, not to mention other consoles that continue to go up in price as US consumers take a beating under tariffs, it’s a refreshing change.

Sadly, the upgraded OLED model of the Steam Deck, with its bigger, br
title: Steam Deck sale! Valve knocks $80 off its amazing PC gaming handheld

description:
Open AI’s CEO Sam Altman writes that the company is rolling out several new, computationally intensive features in the coming weeks.

Due to the high cost, some of the features will initially only be available to Pro subscribers, which costs $200 a month. In addition, some new products may come with additional fees.

“Our intention remains to drive down the cost of intelligence as aggressively as we can and make our services widely available, and we are confident we will get there over time. But we also want to learn what’s possible when we apply a lot of computational power, at today’s modelling costs, to interesting new ideas,” writes Sam Altman.

What these new features are is still unknown.
title: Advanced ChatGPT features will cost extra, even if you pay for Pro

description:
Power banks have become a permanent fixture in my bag. You never know when your phone will die or plans will change, making it a constant companion that keeps me connected. The Baseus Picogo power bank is a solid pick for many reasons, and it’s on sale for $24.69 right now, which is 38 percent off of its $40 MSRP.

This tiny power bank fits into the palm of your hand–a definite advantage since no one wants to lug around another large device. Even better, it has a built-in USB-C cable that doubles as a carrying strap, which is super handy if you take it to a concert, for example. It measures just 3.47 x 2.35 x 1.06 inches, yet still fits a tiny LED display showing remaining battery and charging power.

Speaking of which, this Baseus Picogo model can deliver up to 45W charging via the USB-C
title: This tiny 10,000mAh power bank with a built-in USB-C cable is 38% off

description:
Sometime after my social feeds started to fill up with ads for mini-PCs, I realized that there’s a silent revolution going on in desktop PCs. Welcome to the era of the mini-PC, where you can do all your computing from a PC smaller than a box of Pop-Tarts and much cheaper than a fully fledged desktop PC in many cases.

Naturally, I wanted one, so I bit the bullet and bought a GMKtek G5 mini-PC, the smallest mini-PC of 2024. Now, I couldn’t be happier. The first advantage I noticed was the price. While a new laptop of comparable perf
title: I ditched my laptop for a mini PC and couldn’t be happier
